item.title: The Secret Lives of Country Gentlemen
item.description: Update: Yep. [[books/a noblemans guide to seducing a scoundrel|Second book]] delivers the very necessary half of the whole. I adored it, and now I adore this one on re-read.

item.title: Slippery Creatures
item.description: My favorite KJ Charles yet. I should probably wait till the end of the trilogy to make declarative statements, but there’s WWI spies and bookshops and gentle friendship despite odds and this is as far into my wheelhouse as you can get until, like, sheep herding or Belgium is involved.

item.title: A Marvellous Light
item.description: Fun Edwardian murder mystery. Fun world building. God save Edwin from the idiotic flower of English manhood.

item.title: Parable of the Sower
item.description: I loved the Earthseed parts of this (God is Change), but the dystopia parts went the way of most dystopias for me, almost too limited in its imagination?

item.title: Shadow & Claw
item.description: I think a series that has its own [[books/lexicon urthus|lexicon]] counts for the ultimate feat of [[notes/puzzle-book worldbuilding|puzzle-book worldbuilding]].

item.title: The Adventures of Amina al-Sirafi
item.description: A rollicking pirate adventure AND an extensive bibliography for the historical accuracies! Be still my heart! This was brilliant. It would be easier to make a list of the things I didn’t like about it than all the things I loved.

item.title: The Black Tides of Heaven
item.description: Note from my future self: this makes an excellent prequel, I should have started with [[books/the red threads of fortune|book 2]]!

item.title: The Empress of Salt and Fortune
item.description: If you’re partial to storytelling as lush as this cover art, do not miss Nghi Vo. WOW.

item.title: The Sugared Game
item.description: The reason it takes me a week to read a book that I literally can’t put down is because I read it twice.

item.title: A Restless Truth
item.description: This was so close to being great. SO CLOSE. But overall, the book felt kind of like the menagerie on board the ship, let loose in all directions, refusing to be corralled.

item.title: Sword & Citadel
item.description: Ugh, my [[notes/puzzle-book worldbuilding|puzzle-loving brain]] absolutely loved this. Even all the places where it was like, Gene, your Roman Catholicism is showing.

item.title: The Red Threads of Fortune
item.description: This should have been book 1! Or I should have done my typical thing of reading out of order and started here!

item.title: When the Tiger Came Down the Mountain
item.description: Just as lush and complex as the [[books/the empress of salt and fortune|first one]], and given the smaller scope of the story, arguably my favorite of the two.

item.title: Subtle Blood
item.description: I might have accidentally read Subtle Blood again, since I might have accidentally experienced a vivid dream of Will, Kim, Phoebe, and Maisie on a Parisian adventure (cameo by Teddy Molyneaux, of course), and upon waking, might have accidentally been distraught that that book wasn’t going to exist.

item.title: A Power Unbound
item.description: Here is my theory from [[books/a restless truth|book 2]]: the Blyths suit me best in small doses. Robin and Maud, respectively, were the most difficult parts of their own books for me.

item.title: The Descent of Monsters
item.description: So we’re completely changing protagonists AND writing style AND partially the genre too? Hell yes! Basically it’s the official report on the fallout of the [[books/the red threads of fortune|second book]], done epistolary style (with redactions!

item.title: What My Bones Know
item.description: Incredible memoir. One of the best books I’ve read about healing from abuse, dysfunction, and trauma. So much to relate to on every page (and not just because she had the same Jimmy Eat World song as a lifeline in the early aughts).

item.title: Annals of the Former World
item.description: I’m glad I’m not beyond the age where books I read can change the way I see the world. If that is an age you can reach, I don’t want to.

item.title: Aspects
item.description: The poignancy of having this one cut off, incomplete. What a feat it would have been. What a feat it still is.

item.title: Exodus 20
item.description: If you’re gonna write monster kink, make it a biblically accurate angel. And throw in some searing social/political/theological commentary. This was excellent.

item.title: Gwen & Art Are Not in Love
item.description: I think it wobbled a smiiiidge on the landing, a few things felt abrupt and/or undercooked, not to mention the jarring tonal shift into violence, but the ride to get there was super fun.

item.title: The Found and the Lost
item.description: Le Guin is the master of the novella. Each of these stories contains a universe; even the stories meant to expand the worlds she’s created in her [[series/hainish cycle|Hainish]] and [[series/earthsea cycle|Earthsea]] cycles, they feel complete unto themselves.

item.title: The Lathe Of Heaven
item.description: I can’t remember the last time I read a book with a truly passive protagonist, where his qualities are not his weakness, but his strength.

item.title: Three Kings
item.description: Another for my collection of killer opening lines: Ethan Shaw carried two knives, one for lilies, the other for veins.
